com.njkremer.Sqlite
Class SqlStatement

java.lang.Object
  com.njkremer.Sqlite.SqlStatement

public class SqlStatement
extends java.lang.Object

The main way to interact with the database. This is designed to work with POJOs (Plain Old Java Objects) that "map" to tables in a SQLite Database. This class is really only used to start an statement to work with the database. A SqlExecutor is used to write out the rest of the statement.

Typically a SqlExecutor isn't created on it's own to interact with the database since this class creates a new instance of a SqlExecutor that is returned by all of the methods of this class.

          Deprecated. As of 8/13/2012 the creation of a SqlStatement is deprecated in favor of using the static methods off of the SqlStatement class. The methods will continue to work but you will get compiler warnings to access the methods in a static way.

Method Detail

select

public static <T> SqlExecutor<T> select(java.lang.Class<T> clazz)
                             throws DataConnectionException
Returns a new instance of SqlExecutor to be used for retrieving an Object out of the database.

Parameters:
clazz - A reference to the Object.class that you are retrieving from the database.
Returns:
new SqlExecutor used to retrieve an object from the database.
Throws:
DataConnectionException

update

public static <T> SqlExecutor<T> update(T databaseObject)
                             throws DataConnectionException
Returns a new instance of SqlExecutor to be used for updating an Object in the database.

If you specify a PrimaryKey on your POJO then a "where clause" is not needed when updating an object instead it will use the PrimaryKey to auto generate a where clause.

Parameters:
databaseObject - An object that was queried from the database that has been updated.
Returns:
new SqlExecutor used to update an object in the database.
Throws:
DataConnectionException

insert

public static <T> SqlExecutor<T> insert(T databaseObject)
                             throws DataConnectionException
Returns a new instance of SqlExecutor to be used for inserting an Object into the database.

Note that the values that are set on the passed in POJO will be used for creating the record in the database. If a value isn't set on the POJO than the default Java value will be used (e.g. 0 for int, null for an Object, etc).

Parameters:
databaseObject - An object that is to be input into the database.
Returns:
new SqlExecutor used to insert an object into the database.
Throws:
DataConnectionException

DataConnectionException

delete

public static <T> SqlExecutor<T> delete(T databaseObject)
                             throws DataConnectionException
Returns a new instance of SqlExecutor to be used for deleting an Object in the database.

If you specify a PrimaryKey on your POJO then a "where clause" is not needed when deleting an object instead it will use the PrimaryKey to auto generate a where clause.

Parameters:
databaseObject - An object that should be deleted from the database.
Returns:
new SqlExecutor used to delete an object in the database.
Throws:
DataConnectionException
